qas.question: What does wound colonization refer to?
What type of organisms exist and injure tissue in infected wounds?
What are all multcellular organisms colonized to some degree by?
What species colonizes the mammalian colon?
What's the difference between an infection and a colonization?
What does wound colonization mean to avoid?
What are few multicellular organisms colonized to some degree by?
What type of organisms tickle and heal tissue in infected wounds?
What's the only similarity between an infection and a colonization?
What rodent colonizes the mammalian colon?

context: Wound colonization refers to <a0_0><b5_0>nonreplicating microorganisms within the wound<b5_0/><a0_0/>, while in infected wounds, <a1_0><b7_0>replicating<b7_0/><a1_0/> organisms exist and tissue is injured. All multicellular organisms are colonized to some degree by <a2_0><b6_0>extrinsic organisms<b6_0/><a2_0/>, and the vast majority of these exist in either a mutualistic or commensal relationship with the host. An example of the former is the <a3_0><b9_0>anaerobic bacteria<b9_0/><a3_0/> species, which colonizes the mammalian colon, and an example of the latter is various species of staphylococcus that exist on human skin. Neither of these colonizations are considered infections. The difference between an infection and a colonization is often <a4_0><b8_0>only a matter of circumstance<b8_0/><a4_0/>. Non-pathogenic organisms can become pathogenic given specific conditions, and even the most virulent organism requires certain circumstances to cause a compromising infection. Some colonizing bacteria, such as Corynebacteria sp. and viridans streptococci, prevent the adhesion and colonization of pathogenic bacteria and thus have a symbiotic relationship with the host, preventing infection and speeding wound healing.
